problems.name: Chronic knee pain, osteoarthritis (L>R), intermittent effusions
problems.notes: Pain worsens with stairs and prolonged standing; relief with rest, ice, topical NSAID.

medications.name: Naproxen
medications.notes: Take with food; avoid if stomach upset

medications.name: Omeprazole
medications.notes: GI protection when using NSAIDs as needed

imaging.result: Mild medial compartment narrowing and small osteophytes; no fracture; small suprapatellar effusion.

summary: 50-year-old woman with chronic left-predominant knee osteoarthritis and primary hypothyroidism (well-controlled on levothyroxine). Knee pain with stairs and prolonged standing; uses topical diclofenac, intermittent naproxen. Interested in Ortho/Sports Medicine visit at Downtown Clinic (afternoons; in-person preferred, video acceptable).

entries.text: Chronic knee OA (L>R) with activity-related pain; hypothyroidism controlled (TSH 2.1, free T4 1.1). Prefers Downtown Clinic; afternoons; in-person or video.
Left knee X-ray: mild medial OA changes, small effusion.
Book Orthopedics/Sports Medicine within ~10 days at Downtown Clinic; afternoons; in-person preferred, video acceptable.

Knee OA nonoperative options + thyroid management: exercise therapy (quad/hip strengthening), weight management, topical NSAIDs vs oral NSAIDs, acetaminophen, short-term braces/taping, activity modification, intra-articular corticosteroids; role of hyaluronic acid varies. Hypothyroidism: TSH targets on levothyroxine, adherence, drug interactions.

query_suggestions: topical NSAIDs vs oral NSAIDs knee OA evidence
weight loss exercise therapy knee OA randomized trial
hypothyroidism levothyroxine dosing monitoring TSH adult
